content.content:
The JSTL is build as a jQuery plugin. You must include jQuery and must be completly loaded, befor JSTL are loaded.
The best way is to include jQuery at head!

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<meta charset="utf-8">
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1">
<script type="text/javascript" src="libs/jquery-2.1.1.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="dist/1.6.0/de.titus.jquery.plugins-1.6.0.js"></script>

</head>
<body>
</body>
</html>
You can use jQuery > 1.9.0 and jQuery > 2.0.0.
You can use JSTL for render data to html, to load dynamicly static html fracments or both together. Hier is a "Hello World" sample.

content.headline: "Hello World" Sample
content.content:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<base href="../../../../" />
<meta charset="utf-8"/>
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1"/>
<title>Hello World</title>
<script type="text/javascript" src="libs/jquery-2.1.1.js"></script>
<script type="text/javascript" src="dist/1.6.0/de.titus.jquery.plugins-1.6.0.js"></script>
</head>
<body jstl-data="{text:'Hello World'}" jstl-autorun>
${text}
</body>
</html>

content.headline: line 10: jstl-data
content.content: With "jstl-data" you can define an inline data. At this sample, you define a variable named "text" and put the value "Hello World" on it. You can define at "jstl-data" any data object you want. The syntax is json and starts as an object.

content.headline: line 10: jstl-autorun
content.content: With "jstl-autorun" start the JSTL direct after page load. Its simalar to:

content.headline: line 11: ${text} - Expressions
content.content: At all processing time, you have a data context and with an expression you can get the values from context. At any time you want to access the context, you need an expression. An expression starts normaly with "${" and ends with "}". The inner content of an expression you can have full access to javascript and the current data context.
